channel.title: Comments on: How I Learned JavaScript On Accident

item.title: By: Russell Heimlich
item.dc:creator: Russell Heimlich
item.description: Your spot on! It's also worth mentioning that concatenating strings you use a . in PHP and a + in JavaScript. The hardest part about PHP for me was wading through all of the different methods and properties since there is a whole sloth of similiar-sounding functions.
item.content:encoded: Your spot on! It’s also worth mentioning that concatenating strings you use a . in PHP and a + in JavaScript. The hardest part about PHP for me was wading through all of the different methods and properties since there is a whole sloth of similiar-sounding functions.

item.title: By: Phil Rae (NetInspired)
item.dc:creator: Phil Rae (NetInspired)
item.description: PHP is surprisingly similar-looking to Javascript. I learned Javascript off the back of learning Java at university, then going onto learn PHP as I began making interactive websites for clients in my spare time. The only major different I can think of between PHP and Javascipt (aside from the fact it's backend rather than frontend), is that every variable in PHP starts with a $-sign whereas in Javascript, they don't.
item.content:encoded: PHP is surprisingly similar-looking to Javascript. I learned Javascript off the back of learning Java at university, then going onto learn PHP as I began making interactive websites for clients in my spare time. The only major different I can think of between PHP and Javascipt (aside from the fact it’s backend rather than frontend), is that every variable in PHP starts with a $-sign whereas in Javascript, they don’t.
